stories.headline: Texas Democrats end walkout, allowing redrawn map to pass
stories.summary: Texas Democrats who had previously left the state in a two-week walkout to block a Republican redistricting map have returned, enabling the redrawn congressional map to pass. Republican leaders had sued Democrats and issued arrest warrants to compel their return, but after initially resisting, Democrats came back and Democratic lawmakers are now driving efforts to redraw Texas' congressional map in their favor.

stories.headline: Trump, Zelenskyy meet with eye toward meeting with Putin
stories.summary: President Donald Trump expressed hope for a trilateral meeting with Vladimir Putin and Volodymyr Zelenskyy to advance peace talks regarding the conflict in Ukraine. Trump indicated that if talks go well, a trial meeting could happen soon, and emphasized the importance of ending the war. Despite tensions and past clashes, both leaders have sought further diplomatic efforts, with Ukraine still needing support amid the conflict.

stories.headline: Democrats put weight behind California’s redistricting effort
stories.summary: California Democrats have united to support Governor Gavin Newsom's redistricting initiative ahead of a special November election. More than 30 lawmakers gathered to push new congressional maps and a constitutional amendment aimed at preventing abuse of redistricting power. This effort is part of a broader strategy to enhance fair representation and counteract political manipulation of district boundaries.

stories.headline: Thousands of students flock to area colleges
stories.summary: Move-in week at Pittsburgh-area colleges marks an energetic start to the fall semester as thousands of students arrive. Point Park University President Chris Brusalis noted Monday morning's activities like pompom shaking, pizza giveaways, and exploring Pittsburgh restaurants signal a fun and spirited beginning. Most new students at Point Park and other institutions are freshmen, contributing to a significant rise in enrollment this semester.

stories.headline: Rural Pa. drugstore chain sues to stay afloat
stories.summary: At a senior center in Central City, Pa., Dan Bulger expressed concerns over the future of the town's only drugstore, Penn Laurel Pharmacy, amidst a contract dispute with a major drug benefit manager threatening to close the store. The closure would force residents to travel far for medications. The pharmacy, which has been an anchor for 70 years serving many elderly customers, faces a challenging situation as they pursue legal action to remain operational.

stories.headline: 'IT'S STILL RAW' - Service honors those killed, injured in U.S. Steel explosion
stories.summary: More than 100 members of churches throughout the Mon Valley gathered for an interfaith service at St. Clare of Assisi Church in Clairton to honor those killed and injured in a recent deadly explosion at the U.S. Steel Clairton Coke Works plant. The service featured prayers, candle lighting, and reflections on healing and hope amidst grief and uncertainty following the tragedy.

stories.headline: Garrity launches bid for governor
stories.summary: Pennsylvania Treasurer Stacy Garrity announced her candidacy for governor, setting the stage for a notable race against Josh Shapiro expected to run for re-election in 2026 and the White House in 2028. Garrity, a retired U.S. Army Reserve colonel and businesswoman, pledged via social media to address and fix the problems attributed to Shapiro's administration, running on a platform of remedying issues and challenging him in the upcoming primaries.

stories.headline: TRUMP TAKES INTERMEDIARY ROLE
stories.summary: President Donald Trump has begun arrangements for a face-to-face meeting between Vladimir Putin and Volodymyr Zelenskyy to discuss a pathway to end Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Trump announced he called both leaders and pushed for an end to the brutal war with significant measures of trepidation but with hopes to make concessions that will further the goal of peace.

stories.headline: Businesses, community hubs say they got mixed messages amid manhunt
stories.summary: Following a shelter-in-place order due to a manhunt after a shooting in Windham, local businesses and community centers experienced confusion from unclear communications. More than 100 mourners gathered to honor Henry 'Chuck' Whynot Jr., a local volunteer who passed away recently. The Windham Mall was also impacted as the crime scene there led to a statewide alert and shelter-in-place directives.

stories.headline: Trump, Zelensky express hope for talks with Putin to end Russia-Ukraine war
stories.summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and U.S. President Donald Trump expressed hope that their critical meeting with European leaders and Russian President Vladimir Putin at the White House could lead to bringing an end to the ongoing war in Ukraine. Trump also indicated his hope for peace talks to reduce conflict and tension between the nations.

stories.headline: Back in Maine, former top health official decries Trump administration’s approach
stories.summary: Dr. Nirav Shah, former director of the Maine Center for Disease Control and Prevention and deputy director of the U.S. CDC, criticized the Trump administration's handling of public health during the transition period. Shah spoke in a wide-ranging interview expressing concerns about the future of public health in the U.S. and announced he is considering a run for Maine governor in 2026 as a Democrat.

stories.headline: Program aims to help struggling lobstermen start other businesses
stories.summary: Two Maine nonprofits are launching a program to help lobstermen, their families, and crew members start alternative businesses to cope with economic uncertainty in the lobster industry. The Island Institute and the Maine Center for Entrepreneurs are accepting applications for a new financial literacy and business development course aimed at diversifying incomes outside of lobster fishing, which has become increasingly difficult due to inflation and rising costs.

stories.headline: KC fashion designer goes ‘full throttle’ on style
stories.summary: Sheraz Pompey, a Kansas City fashion designer, developed his passion for fashion from his teenage years and turned his creativity into a professional pursuit. Enrolling at Paseo High School in a fashion design class fueled his ambitions and helped him lay the foundation for a career. Pompey has since co-owned a boutique called The Blueprint KC, and recently discussed how Kansas City's culture has inspired his work and his journey in fashion over 11 years.

stories.headline: Surge of weekend gunfire kills 3, injures 2 in KC area
stories.summary: A surge of gun violence in the Kansas City metro area over the weekend left three people dead and two others wounded. The shootings occurred in different parts of Kansas City and Kansas, with two men and a woman among the victims. Police identified the victims and are investigating, noting that one incident also involved a 14-year-old boy who was shot and wounded.

stories.headline: Farmers market construction reshaping downtown Overland Park
stories.summary: Downtown Overland Park is undergoing major transformation with the construction of the new $34 million Overland Park Farmers Market and Downtown Gathering Space Improvement Project. The project features a modern design that includes covered vendor areas, expanded seating, shade structures, and amenities to enhance visitor comfort. It aims to become a hub for farmers markets, concerts, and community events, with completion expected by the summer of 2026.

stories.headline: Outgoing Independence chief leaves complex legacy
stories.summary: Adam Dustman, the Independence Police Chief, unexpectedly left his position, leaving the department with several pending vacancies and ongoing legal challenges. Dustman requested leave in May after a trip to Washington, D.C., during National Police Week. Prior to his resignation, the department had opened an investigation into his conduct during that trip. Dustman had a long career with the department, joining in 2008 and serving as interim chief before his full-time appointment in 2023.

stories.headline: Meetings end without security guarantee
stories.summary: President Trump, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, and European leaders met at the White House to discuss Ukraine's security amid the ongoing conflict with Russia. Despite talks being described as 'very good,' no concrete security guarantees were made. The discussions also touched on NATO members' roles and the deployment of troops to Ukraine.

stories.headline: D.C. locals welcome fed patrols, safer streets
stories.summary: Robbie Woodland and other locals express approval of President Trump's federal takeover of the District of Columbia police, which has already resulted in around 400 arrests, including homicide suspects and drug traffickers. The move is seen as a positive step toward addressing high crime and disorder in the area.

stories.headline: Tariff on Brazilian coffee brews backlash in U.S.
stories.summary: American consumers face rising coffee costs as a 50% tariff imposed on Brazilian coffee, the world's largest producer, takes effect. This tariff, introduced by President Trump, has caused prices to surge and disrupted supply chains as buyers work to manage the increased costs. Industry experts anticipate further developments as negotiations continue.

stories.headline: IRS blew $500,000 annually on faulty kiosks
stories.summary: The IRS spent about $500,000 each year on self-help kiosks intended to assist taxpayers with digital filing, but the kiosks were largely ineffective. An inspector general revealed that the kiosks were often faulty, wasted resources, and caused longer wait times, with many taxpayers relying on human assistance instead.

stories.headline: 'Lucky' man: Marine veteran reunited with Iwo Jima tank
stories.summary: Leighton Willhite, a Marine veteran who served with the M4A3 Sherman tank called 'Lucky' during the Battle of Iwo Jima, was reunited with the historic tank during a museum visit. This rare moment allowed Willhite to reflect on his service and the tank's storied past, symbolizing a powerful connection to his wartime experiences.

stories.headline: Dems return, declare victory
stories.summary: The Texas House resumed official business after a quorum break delayed congressional redistricting. House Speaker Dustin Burrows confirmed Democrats' departure failed to block the redistricting process, with the majority returning to work and beginning the referral of bills. Democrats won a legislative map court battle that could flip five seats to Republican seats, which included flood relief and abortion legislation. Despite a contentious session, the House strives to proceed with agenda items.

stories.headline: Measles surge subsides
stories.summary: Texas' measles outbreak, which had infected hundreds in 2025 including children, is officially over as cases have not been reported for more than 42 days. The outbreak spread from east to west Texas, and also affected New Mexico and Oklahoma, pushing the state's 2025 cases to the highest in 33 years. The Texas Department of State Health Services notes vaccination declines and community spread were factors in the outbreak, which is now considered ended after no recent reported cases.

stories.headline: Surgical tool left in patient, lawsuit alleges
stories.summary: A surgical team at Baylor University Medical Center allegedly left a nearly 10-inch long surgical tool inside patient Genaro Nava's body following an operation to remove a cancerous tumor. His doctor ordered an X-ray which revealed the foreign object causing pain and high blood pressure. Nava and his attorney are suing Baylor Scott & White Health for the alleged oversight and the trauma experienced.

stories.headline: Leaders search for peace
stories.summary: President Donald Trump has started working on arrangements for a face-to-face meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy to discuss ending Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Trump made the announcement after phone discussions with Putin and hosted Zelenskyy and European leaders to push a diplomatic solution to the war. Plans include a potential trilateral meeting aiming to negotiate a ceasefire and address Ukrainian territory seized by Russia.
people: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen

stories.headline: Trump hosts Zelenskyy at White House
stories.summary: Former President Donald Trump hosted Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy at the White House, marking a significant diplomatic engagement between the US and Ukraine amidst ongoing geopolitical tensions. The meeting focused on strengthening bilateral relations and discussing key issues such as security and economic support.

stories.headline: Hurricane Erin may produce swell in county
stories.summary: Hurricane Erin, a Category 4 storm, is expected to bring wave and rip current threats to Palm Beach County despite missing direct landfalls. The National Weather Service predicts seas of 5 to 9 feet with breaking waves at the beach reaching up to 8 feet during its passage, posing potential risks for beachgoers and residents. Local meteorologists warn of increased swell and caution residents to remain vigilant.

stories.headline: NO CAMERA, NO CLARITY
stories.summary: Florida's top immigration police do not use body-worn cameras, raising concerns among advocates about accountability and transparency. The article recounts an incident where a Florida Highway Patrol officer responded to an altercation involving an immigrant without body camera footage, which complicates investigations and leaves incidents relying solely on limited dash camera views and written accounts.

stories.headline: Florida’s DOGE team auditors arrive in Palm Beach County
stories.summary: Florida's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) auditors have begun reviewing county government budgets in Palm Beach County to identify wasteful spending. The audits cover budget years from 2021 through 2025, focusing on local governments that have shown significant taxpayer revenue increases. DOGE auditors will continue their efforts through August 19 to assess fiscal management and budgeting efficiency.

stories.headline: 'I can make it out of this'
stories.summary: A story focusing on the Santa Fe County Adult Correctional Facility's women’s jail reentry program aimed at reducing recidivism, easing transition, and restoring a sense of normalcy for inmates. The program includes literacy classes, substance abuse relief, and job support, helping inmates break cycles of addiction and criminal charges as they prepare to reintegrate into society.

stories.headline: City panel denies operating permit for Espanola's only homeless shelter
stories.summary: The Espanola Planning Commission denied a special-use permit for the city's only homeless shelter operated by Pathways Shelter board. The decision was rooted in concerns regarding the shelter’s impact despite the shelter's role in keeping people safe and housed. Some local officials emphasized the need to address underlying issues like addiction and mental health differently than forcibly removing people from the streets.

stories.headline: Santa Fe pools shutter early as officials cite staff shortages
stories.summary: Summer swimming season at Bicentennial, Fort Marcy, and Salvador Perez facilities ended earlier than expected by about two weeks due to staff shortages. City Recreation Division Director Brian Stinett cited difficulties in staffing across pools which led to the closure of Bicentennial Pool and limited operation of other pools. Maintenance and replacement projects also disrupted pool hours.

stories.headline: Concerns over felled cemetary trees
stories.summary: Residents in the Historic St. Catherine's neighborhood near the Santa Fe National Cemetery expressed concerns over the clearing of a ridgeline for the cemetery's expansion. Some argue that this clearing may violate terms of deed and alarm neighbors due to the removal of several piñon and juniper trees on the 85-acre property.

stories.headline: NY bill aims to curb food waste through standardized labels
stories.summary: A new bill under consideration in New York seeks to reduce food waste by standardizing food packaging labels. Sponsored by Senator Michelle Hinchey and Assembly member Karines Reyes, Senate Bill S7618 proposes uniform terms like 'Best if Used By' to clearly communicate food safety and peak quality to consumers, replacing ambiguous terms such as 'Use By' or 'Sell By'. This legislative effort aims to help consumers better understand when food is safe to eat and reduce unnecessary disposal of edible products.

stories.headline: ‘Our bodies bear the remnants’
stories.summary: The article discusses the lasting health effects suffered by generations of New Mexicans exposed to nuclear fallout from the Manhattan Project's Trinity Test. Starting with the 1945 detonation of the world's first nuclear weapon, radioactive dust contaminated the surrounding area leading to increased cancer rates among families and neighbors of the test site. Survivors and advocates seek compensation after nearly 80 years of suffering linked to the bomb's aftermath.

stories.headline: ‘Forever chemicals’ in water raise concern
stories.summary: More than 3.5 million New Yorkers are served by water systems detecting PFAS, or 'forever chemicals', which raise health concerns including cancer risks. While some contamination levels are below federal limits, many communities, especially in Long Island, the Hudson Valley, and upstate New York, report presence of these persistent pollutants. The EPA's PFAS testing initiative is nearing completion, with attention turning to removing these chemicals and extending deadlines for implementing filtration systems beyond the original 2029 target.

stories.headline: Dart stays hot in impressive preseason showing
stories.summary: The sports story highlights Dart's outstanding performance in the preseason, showcasing his excellent skills and promising potential for the upcoming season. His continued strong play has impressed fans and analysts alike, signaling a hot streak as the official games approach.

stories.headline: A portentous trend: rising joblessness among Blacks
stories.summary: Specialists report that the unemployment rate for Black workers is rising, with the Black and Latino 12-month average unemployment rates in Massachusetts hitting nearly a four-year high. While nationwide unemployment is around 5 percent for Blacks, Massachusetts shows a higher trend, signaling a potential weakening in the economy and disparities in job recovery among racial groups.

stories.headline: Inquiry could upend hiring policy beyond Harvard
stories.summary: The US government is investigating Harvard University for alleged discrimination against whites, Asians, and men in its hiring practices, part of a broader Trump administration campaign challenging affirmative action policies. This inquiry could lead to changes in employment practices not only at Harvard but potentially other institutions as well.

stories.headline: Zelensky seeks security vows
stories.summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, supported by an extraordinary delegation of European leaders, met with President Trump at the White House to discuss a road map to peace in Ukraine. Trump is pushing for a quick peace deal, which would require Ukraine to make significant concessions. The meeting was noted for its cordiality and willingness to work towards ending the conflict.

stories.headline: Trump looks to eliminate voting by mail-in ballots
stories.summary: President Trump, amid a series of misstatements on social media, announced his intention to end mail-in voting, claiming concerns about fraud. This comes alongside efforts to redraw voting maps and increased Republican efforts to restrict voting access, though legal challenges and constitutional protections remain significant hurdles to these measures.

stories.headline: Brazilian rap battle strikes a chord in community
stories.summary: In Cambridge, a rap battle event at North Point Park has brought together a community of over two dozen people through spirited lyrical exchanges in Portuguese featuring participants like Tyler Lopes and Breno Pio. The rap battles provide a space for artistic expression and conversation on personal struggles such as depression, resonating with the community and making the event a local cultural highlight.

stories.headline: Texas Democrats come back to Austin
stories.summary: Texas House Democrats ended their 15-day walkout and returned to Austin to address congressional redistricting after delaying it previously. The Democrats, who are outnumbered in the Texas House, landed in Austin to resume legislative sessions. Their absence had denied the House quorum and stalled the process, but Republicans are now expected to quickly pass the new map affecting the 2026 midterms. The walkout was unlikely to stop the redistricting plan despite the Democrats' efforts.

stories.headline: State: Measles outbreak is over
stories.summary: The Texas measles outbreak, lasting nearly seven months and infecting more than 750 people, including two young girls who died, is officially over according to the Texas Department of State Health Services. The outbreak began in South Plains and spread across the state, mainly in communities with low vaccination rates. Public health and disease control efforts, including testing, vaccination, and education, helped contain the outbreak, but experts caution about possible future flare-ups if vaccination rates don't improve.

stories.headline: Trump seeking meeting of Russia, Ukraine
stories.summary: President Donald Trump announced he is arranging a face-to-face meeting between Vladimir Putin and Volodymyr Zelenskyy to discuss ending Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The announcement followed talks between Trump and Putin, with Trump emphasizing the importance of a pathway to end the war. Russian officials suggested continued cooperation between Russian and Ukrainian delegations. The potential meeting comes amid ongoing conflict and complex diplomatic negotiations.

stories.headline: Camp cabins and homes taken off risk maps before flooding
stories.summary: Flash floods on July 4 severely damaged properties including Philip Roberson's home along the Guadalupe River, which was not on flood risk maps despite its vulnerability. After purchasing the home, Roberson found the house was above the 100-year floodplain according to FEMA, but floods still caused major damage. Researchers suggest that current FEMA flood maps underestimate flood risk, especially in areas like Hill Country which recently experienced heavy flooding affecting homes and camps like Camp Mystic.

stories.headline: MPCA response to plant draws ire
stories.summary: Residents near a battery recycler in Eagan have voiced frustration over delayed information about elevated lead levels linked to the plant. The Minnesota Pollution Control Agency's failure to promptly notify neighbors of high lead levels detected in January, February, and March has caused community anger. Locals say the agency's continued communications have been inadequate in protecting families, with some children possibly exposed to toxic lead in their neighborhood.

stories.headline: Reports of unsafe drinking water rise
stories.summary: Mound Mayor Jason Holt reported unsafe levels of manganese in the city's drinking water supply, a problem persisting for four years. Despite the installation of a special treatment system, the issue remains due to costly and complex solutions. Mound joins dozens of Minnesota cities facing similar challenges with manganese contamination in their water systems. Residents and officials debate how to fund and implement effective new facilities to ensure safe drinking water.

stories.headline: Trump making plans for Zelenskyy, Putin to meet
stories.summary: President Donald Trump has initiated arrangements for a face-to-face meeting between Vladimir Putin and Volodymyr Zelenskyy to explore a path to end the Ukraine conflict. The announcement followed a phone call with Putin and a hosting of Zelenskyy at the White House to discuss security guarantees and potential concessions. While details on Putin's commitment remain unclear, the U.S. pressures Ukraine for concessions that risk emboldening Putin, amid ongoing talks involving European leaders.

stories.headline: Russia pounds Ukraine ahead of White House meeting
stories.summary: Russia has intensified missile attacks on Ukraine ahead of a scheduled White House meeting seeking security guarantees. New strikes targeted civilians and facilities in Zaporizhzhia and other regions, causing significant casualties. Zelenskyy emphasized the need for U.S. participation in talks for Ukraine's security in response to ongoing aggression. Pressure mounts as European leaders and the U.S. discuss potential peace agreements amid continued Russian violence.

stories.headline: Drive, bike or ride to the fair like a pro
stories.summary: The Minnesota State Fair is introducing new parking fees and rules this year, including a $25 charge for fairgoers parking on Falcon Heights streets. The city council imposed the fee to manage the lengthy and heated debate over parking impacts. The State Fair encourages the use of express buses, park-and-ride shuttles, and parking fees payable online to ease congestion. Tips and maps are provided to help visitors navigate the parking changes during the 12-day event.

stories.headline: He lost his sight in Berlin
stories.summary: Jose Lopez Masso lost his sight at age 32 due to glaucoma but has since dedicated his life to helping others find independence in Florida. A former diplomat’s son who grew up in East Germany, Lopez Masso now works at the Lighthouse of Broward, providing essential resources, training, and support to the visually impaired. Despite his vision loss and surgeries, he has built a fulfilling life with his wife and daughter and continues to be an advocate for the blind community.

stories.headline: How did truck driver in fatal Turnpike crash get license despite not being legal U.S. resident?
stories.summary: The semi-truck driver involved in a fatal crash on the Florida Turnpike was found not to be a legal U.S. resident, raising questions about how he obtained a commercial driver's license. The crash killed three people and happened around mile marker 3. The driver, Harjinder Singh, is facing scrutiny regarding the legitimacy of his documents and licensing, which involved crossing the U.S.-Mexico border. Officials are investigating the incident and the driver's background.

stories.headline: 'Direct insult.' Victim in Key Biscayne gymnastics coach case demands trial
stories.summary: A victim in the Key Biscayne gymnastics coach sexual abuse case has rejected a plea agreement, calling it a "direct insult" and demanding a trial. The Miami-Dade State Attorney's Office is reconsidering the plea based on the victim's feedback. The accused coach, Oscar Olea, faces charges of sexually assaulting girls over a decade ago. Two other former students have also come forward with allegations. The court has yet to decide whether to uphold or withdraw the plea agreement.

stories.headline: Tariffs to give state’s tomato farmers relief
stories.summary: Michigan tomato farmers have been heavily impacted by tariff policies, specifically a 17% tariff President Donald Trump imposed on tomatoes from Mexico. This tariff imposed last month may help Michigan farmers compete better in the market, despite ongoing struggles with labor shortages and competition from cheaper Mexican tomatoes. Farmer Fred Lietz from Sodus Township expresses cautious optimism that the federal government will take further action to support local growers.

stories.headline: Trump urges direct Putin-Zelenskyy talks
stories.summary: President Donald Trump has advocated for direct negotiations between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy to resolve the conflict in Ukraine. Trump suggested that face-to-face talks could help address territorial disputes and ongoing tensions following Russia's military actions in Ukraine. The President emphasized the importance of diplomacy and expressed hope that such talks would improve relations and support peace efforts.

stories.headline: EV sales jump as tax credits ending
stories.summary: There has been a notable surge in electric vehicle (EV) sales as the expiration of federal tax credits approaches. Michael MacGillivray, who planned to replace his gas-powered car with an EV, illustrates this trend, with buyers rushing to take advantage of nearly $7,500 credits available for first-time EV purchasers. This spike is reflected in the broader market, particularly involving Tesla models, driven by concerns over the end of these incentives on September 30.

stories.headline: Defamation in Tea Dating posts alleged
stories.summary: Several lawsuits have been filed in Metro Detroit against the Tea Dating Advice app, which was designed to warn women about poor or dangerous dating behaviors. The app, popular on social media, faces legal challenges claiming defamation and reputational harm due to posts made on the app. The lawsuits reflect growing concerns over the app's impact on its users and its handling of sensitive information, with cases including a recent filing by Nathan Lirato in Oakland County Circuit Court.

stories.headline: Father’s attempt to stand up for daughter ends in death
stories.summary: Latisha McMillen's family friend, Eric McMillen, was allegedly killed by the daughter's boyfriend during an incident stemming from an attempt to defend Latisha. Eric's death has brought attention to the tragic circumstances surrounding the confrontation, highlighting the emotional impact on the family and ongoing safety concerns in the community.

stories.headline: Construction underway on O’Hare terminal
stories.summary: Following years of negotiations and delays, construction has started on key projects to overhaul O’Hare International Airport. Efforts are focused on what will become the airport's new Concourse D, marking a significant step forward for one of the nation's major airport hubs and promising enhanced passenger experiences upon completion.

stories.headline: Texas Democrats return to home state
stories.summary: Texas House Democrats returned to their state Capitol after spending two weeks out of state to prevent the Republican majority from passing a new gerrymandered congressional map aimed at eliminating Democratic seats. Their return sets the stage for continued political battles as Democrats work to maintain representation in the Texas legislature.

stories.headline: Excitement amid cuts
stories.summary: Families and community members faced the first day of school in Chicago Public Schools amid significant financial uncertainty and budget cuts. Despite the buzz of children starting school, concerns remain as CPS officials cope with a $734 million budget deficit, leading to cuts in various programs including English language learning and social-emotional support. Teachers and parents expressed mixed feelings as district leaders prepared financial roadmaps to address the crisis.

stories.headline: La Grange eliminates honorary street name
stories.summary: La Grange Village Board removed the honorary name of a street previously named after attorney William John Linklater following allegations from the lawyer's daughter that he sexually abused her as a child. Despite longstanding ties to the community, the board acted to change the name due to these serious accusations raised during a public comment session, highlighting ongoing community concerns over the legacy of the namesake.

stories.headline: Ukraine talks come to White House
stories.summary: President Donald Trump initiated arrangements for a face-to-face meeting between Vladimir Putin and Volodymyr Zelenskyy to discuss a pathway to end Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Trump announced progress in talks during a call with Zelenskyy and European leaders, expressing optimism about a potential ceasefire and direct negotiations between the Russian and Ukrainian delegations. The developments reflect ongoing diplomatic efforts to resolve the war.

stories.headline: Trump says plan for Putin, Zelenskyy meeting has begun
stories.summary: President Donald Trump has initiated arrangements for a face-to-face meeting between Vladimir Putin and Volodymyr Zelenskyy to discuss a pathway to end Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The proposed meeting, referred to as a 'Trilat,' aims to bring both leaders together with European leaders to negotiate an end to the war. While details and timing are still being coordinated, the initiative marks an effort to re-engage direct talks after extensive ongoing conflict.

stories.headline: Microsoft launches review of surveillance in Gaza
stories.summary: Microsoft announced it is conducting an independent review of the use of its cloud computing technology by the Israeli Defense Forces following media reports and pressure from employees and activists. The review aims to assess whether Microsoft's Azure cloud platform was used to target or harm people in Gaza, following internal investigations that previously found no evidence of misuse. Microsoft reaffirmed its commitment to providing cybersecurity and professional services to governments while responding to concerns about ethical use.

stories.headline: Costco won't sell abortion pill, citing 'lack of demand'
stories.summary: Costco announced it will not sell the abortion pill due to low demand, continuing its practice of not stocking the medication. Despite questions about potential future changes, Costco remains firm on this decision. Conservative groups praised the move, while major retailers including Costco have refrained from distributing abortion medication citing business concerns and demand uncertainty.

stories.headline: Trump targets all-mail elections like Washington state's
stories.summary: President Donald Trump launched an attack on vote-by-mail, using Washington state's all-mail elections as a primary example. He claimed that all-mail voting invites fraud and increases the risk of corrupt practices, despite evidence suggesting Washington's system is successful and trusted by voters. These statements continue his broader criticism of mail-in voting since his 2020 defeat, aimed at casting doubt on election integrity.

stories.headline: Fire supported our forests. Can we get that back?
stories.summary: The article discusses the historical role of fire in sustaining forests, particularly around the Great Lakes region where natural fires were once a regular occurrence but have been largely suppressed for the last 150 years. Evan Larson, a geography professor at the University of Wisconsin-Platteville, leads research that suggests traditional controlled burns and natural fire patterns helped maintain forest and plant biodiversity. The story highlights the importance of reintroducing such fire practices to revitalize ecosystems.

stories.headline: 211 data provide picture of extent, areas of flooding damage
stories.summary: Wisconsin's 211 helpline received over 11,500 flood-related requests following extensive rainfall and flooding from August 9-10. About 85% of the calls came from Milwaukee County and nearby areas. The 211 data reveal the scope of damage, including widespread utility disruptions and emergency needs. This information helps connect residents with services such as housing, food, and disaster cleanup. The highest number of requests were from Milwaukee County's northwest side, particularly ZIP codes 53218, 53209, and 53216.

stories.headline: Trump, Zelenskyy discuss peace
stories.summary: President Donald Trump met with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy to discuss peace efforts concerning the conflict between Russia and Ukraine. This meeting marked a more respectful and constructive tone compared to a previous meeting when Trump mocked Zelenskyy. Trump expressed hope for a long-term peace agreement beyond a short-term truce and emphasized the importance of making sure progress is made in the ongoing talks.

stories.headline: Forecasters keep eye on 2nd Atlantic system as Erin remains major hurricane
stories.summary: Hurricane Erin, a Category 4 storm as of Monday evening, is expected to weaken by Tuesday. Forecasters indicate another system in the Atlantic has a medium chance of development, but is unlikely to pose a threat to Florida. Erin's projected path threatens the Outer Banks of North Carolina, with a potential follow-up system named Fernand possible if it strengthens enough.

stories.headline: Judge issues Alligator Alcatraz ruling
stories.summary: A federal judge in Miami dismissed a key claim in a lawsuit over Alligator Alcatraz detainees' access to courts and legal services, moving the case to a different district. The ruling noted that the immigration court handling the cases had changed, resolving allegations that detainees were denied legal access. However, one claim alleging a lack of confidential and swift access to attorneys remains. The ruling comes after a month of detainees being brought to the Alligator Alcatraz facility for their cases.

stories.headline: Seeking relief from the heat
stories.summary: Visitors to the Dunedin Causeway sought relief from the hot and humid weather by sheltering in pop-up tents and engaging in water activities such as paddling. The day was mostly sunny, with locals and visitors taking advantage of the warm weather conditions.

stories.headline: Trump says he has begun arrangements for Putin, Zelenskyy to meet face-to-face
stories.summary: President Donald Trump announced that he has begun arrangements for a face-to-face meeting between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy to discuss the ongoing war. Trump made the announcement after phone calls with both leaders, expressing hope to end the conflict. Officials have confirmed these efforts, but details about the agreement or meeting timeline remain unclear.

stories.headline: WMNF co-founder and longtime Tampa Bay radio, TV voice Rob Lorei dies
stories.summary: Rob Lorei, co-founder of community radio station WMNF-FM and longtime voice on Tampa Bay radio and TV, passed away after a battle with cancer. Lorei publicly announced his diagnosis in March and continued to be active in media and community work. He was known for moderating a weekly panel show and had a career spanning decades, including a political ad and fundraising efforts during his final months.

stories.headline: Smoke and heat force vulnerable Michiganders indoors
stories.summary: Many Michiganders, including Stasia Cole, are struggling to avoid overheating and the harmful effects of smoke from Canadian wildfires. The region has experienced high temperatures and smoke-filled winds, worsening air quality and causing health problems like asthma and difficulty breathing. These conditions are partly driven by climate change and report increasing risks during summer months.

stories.headline: Complicated property tax system is all over the map
stories.summary: The property tax system in Michigan is highly complex, involving overlapping tax units like counties, cities, townships, and school districts, which creates wide variations in property tax rates. The median tax bill for a Michigan residence was $2,845 in 2023. Different areas and school districts within cities like Grand Rapids have varying millage rates, affecting the taxable values and taxes owed. The article explains how property tax rates and millage have fluctuated and highlights key facts about the state's taxing system.

stories.headline: Traditional marriage celebration stirs debate
stories.summary: The Ottumwa City Council faces debate after Pastor Travis Decker and a leader at Ottumwa Baptist Temple promoted a traditional marriage parade featuring imagery like a bride and groom, red roses, and slogans of fidelity and purity. The Aug. 23 event has sparked controversy, leading to a heated City Council meeting with applause, boos, and shouting over the proclamation and the event’s appropriateness.

stories.headline: Trump hosts Zelenskyy at White House
stories.summary: In February, President Donald Trump mocked Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy as "disrespectful" during a prior meeting. However, on Aug. 18, Trump hosted Zelenskyy again at the White House, where both presidents expressed thanks, with Zelenskyy wearing a black suit and a European leaders' contingent attending as well. This visit contrasts sharply with the tension seen in their previous encounter.

stories.headline: Dairy Zone spins tradition into award-winning fame
stories.summary: Dairy Zone's supplier of butter cake underestimated the demand from Iowa State fairgoers who love their ice cream and treats, including a blend of thick vanilla ice cream, butter cake, and butterscotch syrup crowned with a white chocolate cow. Co-owners Carolyn Farrell and Kim Gilmore received the Choose Iowa Favorite Fair Food Award during the annual concessionaire honors, celebrating their rapid popularity in just their second year on the fairgrounds.

stories.headline: How a Modest Income Supports a Big Family
stories.summary: Brittany Ivy and Michael, a couple without much money, created a large family by managing their finances carefully and living modestly. They took advantage of home construction jobs, bought used items, and managed expenses while raising ten children. Their story highlights the challenges and commitment of supporting a big family on limited resources.

stories.headline: An 11-Year-Old Boy on a Boat Stirs Pride and Envy in Indonesia
stories.summary: Rayyan Arkan Dikha, an 11-year-old rowing star from Indonesia, has become a sensation by winning races in a traditional sport despite his young age. He is celebrated locally and globally, inspiring pride among Indonesians and stirring envy among his competitors. His skill and dedication have turned him into a role model for youth in the region.

stories.headline: A New Reality for Terminal Cancer
stories.summary: Gwen Orilio, a patient with terminal cancer, is living longer than expected due to new treatments and ongoing care. Although the disease is still fatal, advancements in treatment have extended survival times and improved quality of life for many patients with late-stage cancer, creating a new reality for sufferers and their families.

stories.headline: JPMorgan’s $3 Billion Bet Shows NYC Office Revival
stories.summary: The New York City office market is recovering from its pandemic debacle faster than any other in the U.S. JPMorgan Chase’s new billion-square-foot gleaming tower is a part of this revival. Office visits have surged and the firm’s office footprint is growing, suggesting a potential return to office space demand and investment confidence in New York City after a difficult pandemic period.

stories.headline: U.S. Urges Zelensky, Putin to Meet
stories.summary: President Trump urged Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and Russian President Vladimir Putin to meet face to face with him at a peace conference in a long-shot U.S.-led bid to end the 3½-year-long war in Ukraine. Zelensky embraced the idea of a three-way summit quickly, but Putin indicated that any meeting would need to follow one-on-one talks first.

stories.headline: Trump Seeks End Of Mail-In Voting
stories.summary: President Trump has renewed his calls to end mail-in voting in the upcoming midterm elections, critiquing the practice as susceptible to error and fraud. Trump has urged Republican-led states and congressmen to help pass requirements for stricter identification and prohibitions on counting absentee or mail-in ballots received after Election Day. This move carries significant political implications for how elections are conducted nationwide.

stories.headline: Trump supports talks between Russia, Ukraine
stories.summary: President Donald Trump expressed support for talks with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and European leaders aimed at a potential ceasefire and lifting Russian sanctions. Trump said the talks would involve the U.S., Russia, and Ukraine, and showed willingness to guarantee security for Ukraine alongside European allies. He emphasized the importance of dialogue and protection efforts during his meeting at the White House.

stories.headline: State: Measles outbreak is over
stories.summary: The Texas measles outbreak has officially ended according to the Department of State Health Services after 42 days since the last reported positive case. The 2025 outbreak resulted in 762 reported cases and 99 hospitalizations, including two deaths. The outbreak was managed with a comprehensive response including testing, vaccination, and public education. The outbreak began in West Texas, eventually spreading to 37 counties, with some counties not linked to the West Texas outbreak.

stories.headline: Texas Democrats come back to Austin
stories.summary: Texas House Democrats returned to Austin on Monday morning after ending a 15-day walkout. Their absence had denied the House the two-thirds members required to make up a quorum, aiming to stop a congressional redistricting plan that would protect the Republican majority in Congress after the 2026 midterms. Though they have returned, Republicans in the Legislature are expected to quickly take up and pass the new plan.

stories.headline: Funeral agency official's texts about Islam raise questions
stories.summary: Questions have arisen regarding texts sent by the Texas Funeral Service Commission chair to the agency's executive director, containing misleading claims about Islam. The texts were obtained via public records and covered topics such as Islamic teachings and terrorism risks posed to American society. The issue came to light amid ongoing scrutiny of the funeral service commission's activities and claimed agenda.

stories.headline: From a storied past to an uncertain future
stories.summary: Indiana Landmarks has released its 2025 list of 10 endangered sites, highlighting historic locations such as Mineral Springs Hotel in Paoli and Kiwanis Field in La Porte. These sites face risks due to neglect, funding shortages, and development pressures, threatening their survival despite their architectural and cultural significance.

stories.headline: Affordable housing planned for Indy
stories.summary: A Carmel-based developer, Sullivan Development, plans to invest over $70 million to add more than 270 low-income apartment units by 2027 across multiple Indianapolis sites. The Indianapolis City-County Council approved a $3.7 million local tax break, and the project also benefits from $29 million in federal low-income housing tax credits, aiming to address the city's growing need for affordable rentals amid rising rents.

stories.headline: Inmates say Indiana prison's AC fix still failing in summer heat
stories.summary: Inmates at Heritage Trail Correctional Facility complain that despite recent air conditioning repairs by the private prison operator, the AC is still not functional in one wing housing 187 inmates. Complaints include health complications linked to the ongoing heat. The Department of Correction spokesperson confirms the issues, but exact timelines for repair completion are unclear. Legal involvement by the American Civil Liberties Union of Indiana is noted.
people: American Civil Liberties Union of Indiana

stories.headline: BART director rebuilt his life after prison
stories.summary: Victor Flores, a BART Board Director, has transformed his life from a troubled past including incarceration to becoming a dedicated public servant working to improve the financially challenged transit agency. The story details his personal journey, insights into his priorities, and his role in leading BART's efforts for better transit support and accessibility.

stories.headline: The secret beneath Crystal Springs
stories.summary: This story explores the history and hidden aspects beneath Crystal Springs Reservoir in San Mateo County. Few hikers using this trail are aware of the submerged hotel and farms beneath the water. The article includes historical reflections and highlights the recreational and natural beauty of the area surrounding the reservoir.

stories.headline: Heat wave expected across California this week
stories.summary: California is anticipating a significant heat wave beginning midweek and lasting through the weekend, with record-breaking temperatures expected in deserts, mountains, and valleys. San Francisco is likely to be spared from the worst. The weather service warns of increased fire risks due to dry lightning and subtropical moisture from the North American Monsoon.

stories.headline: ICE arrests of people with no convictions surge
stories.summary: ICE arrests in Northern California have surged this summer, reflecting a rise in arrest numbers under national immigration enforcement trends. The Department of Homeland Security claims the arrests target individuals involved in serious crimes, but data analysis indicates a large number of arrests include people without criminal convictions. The article discusses the impacts and implications of these enforcement actions.

stories.headline: 'It's beautiful': After a $30M fix-up, historic Frankford High reopens
stories.summary: Frankford High School, closed since April 2023 due to asbestos damage, has reopened following a $30 million renovation. The building, an iconic Gothic Revival structure, underwent extensive asbestos removal and installation of protective ceiling tiles, paneling, and new classrooms and offices. Principal Michael Calderone praised the upgrades as transformative, calling it the best day of his career. The school now boasts improved air conditioning, new windows, and enhanced safety while maintaining its historic character.

stories.headline: Trump says he will 'lead a movement' to change voting
stories.summary: President Donald Trump announced plans to sign an executive order banning mail-in ballots and voting machines, asserting states hold the power to run elections but he wants to 'bring honesty' to the 2026 Midterm Elections. He spoke critically about mail-in ballots and voting processes, citing the 2020 election loss. Meanwhile, a conservative network plans to pay $67 million to settle a lawsuit accusing it of spreading lies about Trump's 2020 election loss. Trump aims to 'lead a movement' against mail-in voting, despite legal and political challenges.

stories.headline: Europeans try to sway Trump away from Putin
stories.summary: Leaders of Ukraine, NATO, and European countries presented a united front in Washington, pressing President Donald Trump to steer away from concessions to Russia over the war in Ukraine. Despite a polite reception to Ukrainian President Zelensky, sharp differences on key issues like Crimea and Donbas remain, with demands for Ukraine to retain strategically important territory. French and German leaders aimed to frame a ceasefire and renewed Ukraine defense aid as imperatives, but Trump has yet to concede a verbal attack on Putin.

stories.headline: SEPTA standoff puts key Amtrak line at risk
stories.summary: U.S. Rep. Brendan Boyle warned that planned funding cuts to SEPTA could force Amtrak to cut the Keystone Service line connecting Philadelphia to Harrisburg. The line, which operates along the Amtrak-owned Northeast Corridor, is at risk due to delayed payments from SEPTA for transit agency operation funds. If the Keystone Service ceases, it would eliminate key rail lines in the region, affecting passengers and electricity generated by Amtrak for trains. Boyle emphasized the urgency of resolving the funding disputes.

stories.headline: Cop Who Fatally Shot Partner Says He’s the Victim in Bar Fight
stories.summary: Carlos Baker, a police officer, claims he is the victim in a bar fight that resulted in the fatal shooting of his partner. This story is part of a watchdog report.

stories.headline: Fun, Fears on First Day
stories.summary: CPS students head back to class with high hopes and some nerves as the Board of Education vote looms to close a $734 million budget deficit, marking the start of a new school year at Mary E. Courtenay Language Arts Center.

stories.headline: Zelenskyy, Trump Hope for Talks with Putin
stories.summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and U.S. President Donald Trump hope their meeting could lead to peace talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin. However, Judge Anna J. Bongartz criticized Zelenskyy for showing insufficient gratitude for U.S. military assistance. Trump emphasized his commitment to ending the conflict and highlighted the importance of successful negotiations.

stories.headline: SLPS Transportation Hit or Miss
stories.summary: Some students in tornado-ravaged neighborhoods wait up to an hour as a new transportation company begins service amid school bus shortages in St. Louis Public Schools due to lingering difficulties from last year's tornado damage. The transition to new vendors and relocations of schools caused delays and cancellations impacting families and students.

stories.headline: Data Center Project is Dead
stories.summary: The developer of a controversial 440-acre data center in St. Charles has withdrawn plans after facing weeks of community opposition and concerns about pollution, wildlife, and environmental impact. The move followed a citizen group investigation request and local government discussion, marking an end to the Project Cumulus proposal.

stories.headline: Former KMOV Employee Wins Discrimination Case
stories.summary: A former KMOV station owner has been ordered to pay $826,000 in damages to Meghan Danahay following a lawsuit alleging discrimination and retaliation triggered by anxiety and depression after her complaints. The court found the station's news director did not respond to requests for comment, and Danahay was ruled to have faced workplace discrimination.

stories.headline: Mayors: Trump profiling cities
stories.summary: Mayor Barbara Lee and other officials in California along with other Black mayors across the country are concerned about President Donald Trump's warning to send the National Guard to cities primarily led by Black Democrats, including Oakland, Los Angeles, Chicago, and Washington, DC. They view the warning as racial profiling and call for federal government intervention to address the issue, highlighting the potential negative impact on these communities.

stories.headline: Ocean depths hold clue to life beyond Earth
stories.summary: Scientists have discovered strange organisms at 31,000 feet deep in the northwest Pacific Ocean that derive energy from chemical reactions rather than sunlight. These findings shed new light on potential life forms in extreme environments, such as extraterrestrial oceans like Jupiter's moon Europa. The discovery was made using a human-crewed submersible vehicle and suggests chemical compounds like methane could support life beyond Earth, expanding our understanding of life's possibilities in the universe.

stories.headline: Can you afford to keep your friendships?
stories.summary: A study shows that 69% of Generation Z and millennials prioritize in-person socializing weekly but face financial pressure to maintain an active social life. Maria Stevens, a 25-year-old, shares her experience of maxed-out credit cards partly due to social commitments and financial strain. The article highlights that socializing and financial strain may be linked, with many in this generation overspending on social activities and not budgeting effectively according to a new survey by Ally Bank.

stories.headline: School board member resigns for job in Virginia
stories.summary: Tiara Booker-Dwyer, a member of Baltimore County Public Schools Board of Education, is resigning to take a new position in Virginia’s education department, prompting a seat vacancy in the Baltimore board.

stories.headline: More questions about the ankle monitor policy
stories.summary: Questions continue about the effectiveness and implementation of new changes to the ankle monitor policy for juveniles who commit crimes, as authorities review its impact and public concerns.

stories.headline: Fagan Harris to lead Abell Foundation
stories.summary: Fagan Harris, previously the chief of staff to Governor Wes Moore, has been selected as the next president of the Abell Foundation. The foundation is a major Baltimore-based nonprofit that manages over $300 million in assets and spends about $15 million annually. Harris brings extensive experience in policy, governance, and community engagement.

stories.headline: Top Democrats don't respond to nonprofit transparency query
stories.summary: A partnership involving Spotlight on Maryland, The Sun, WBFF FOX45, and WJLA launched an investigation into how taxpayer money is allocated to Maryland nonprofits and how those dollars are spent. However, top Democratic leaders in Maryland, including Governor Wes Moore, House Speaker Adrienne A. Jones, and Senate President Bill Ferguson, did not respond to inquiries about ensuring transparency and accountability around nonprofit funding.

stories.headline: Vaccination exemptions are on the rise in Maryland schools
stories.summary: Maryland schools, including Pikesville Middle School, have witnessed an increase in vaccination exemptions, with parents citing COVID vaccine concerns among other reasons. Public health officials warn this trend could impact community immunity and contribute to outbreaks of preventable diseases like polio and measles.

stories.headline: Councilwoman Ramos aims to tax vacant lots
stories.summary: Odette Ramos is pursuing efforts to develop Baltimore’s vacant properties by introducing a bill to tax falling vacant lots, aiming to improve property management and neighborhood conditions.

stories.headline: Face to face meeting sought about Ukraine
stories.summary: President Donald Trump announced plans to set up a direct meeting between himself, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, and Russian President Vladimir Putin. This effort aims to discuss a possible path to end the Ukraine conflict, with Trump also mentioning discussions about war, trials, and agreements involving European leaders.

stories.headline: Justice Department agrees to give Epstein probe files to Congress
stories.summary: The U.S. Justice Department has agreed to share documents with Congress related to the Jeffrey Epstein sex trafficking investigation. This move follows ongoing scrutiny over the Trump administration’s handling of this matter and involves a potential clash over separation of powers between branches of government.

stories.headline: A drying Great Salt Lake holds a new hazard
stories.summary: The Great Salt Lake in Utah is rapidly drying up, exposing lakebed dust that carries carcinogenic threats. Frequent dust storms caused by the shrinking lake pose serious health risks due to heavy metals and chemicals in the dust. This environmental crisis threatens the surrounding communities and calls attention to the urgent need for action to address water management and climate impacts on the lake.

stories.headline: Rights cases flip under Trump
stories.summary: The Trump administration has increased civil rights enforcement at K-12 schools and colleges, focusing on cases involving transgender students and students of color. However, the Education Department's Office for Civil Rights is understaffed and overwhelmed, causing delays and unresolved complaints. The office has a significant backlog and fewer cases are being closed, highlighting challenges in addressing equity issues in education.

stories.headline: In Ukraine talks, little movement toward deal
stories.summary: European and NATO leaders met with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and U.S. President Donald Trump to discuss peace efforts in Ukraine amid ongoing conflict with Russia. Despite the talks, sharp differences remain, particularly with Trump rejecting a ceasefire, complicating potential concessions and peace negotiations. The leaders continue to wrestle with security guarantees, territorial concerns, and the humanitarian impact of the war.

stories.headline: Ukrainians feel war’s staggering cost in children’s lives
stories.summary: The war in Ukraine has resulted in devastating human costs, with a significant increase in deaths and injuries among children. Attacks and missile strikes have caused tragic losses for families. The report highlights the severe impact of the conflict on civilians, emphasizing the urgent need for peace and security to protect Ukraine's most vulnerable population.

stories.headline: AI creators finding gold in flood of fake videos
stories.summary: AI-generated deepfake videos are proliferating rapidly, with creators taking advantage of the technology to produce engaging but false content. One creator, Luis Talavera, has gained attention for making high-volume AI videos that combine humor and social commentary. The spread of deepfakes raises concerns about misinformation and the challenge of discerning real from fake online.

stories.headline: Democrats are returning to Texas, clearing way for GOP to draw new map
stories.summary: Texas Republicans have moved forward with a new congressional map favoring their party after Democrats initially boycotted the process. The newly proposed map reshapes districts, aiming to solidify GOP control in next year's elections. Democrats, however, plan to fight the redistricting efforts. The political battle over Texas's district lines showcases ongoing partisan tensions in the state ahead of upcoming elections.

stories.headline: Chattanooga gears up for long and busy fall tourism season
stories.summary: Downtown Chattanooga is preparing for a busy fall tourism season with hundreds of thousands of visitors attending events like the World of Bluegrass Festival and more than 80,000 events expected in September and November. Donna Elle Harrison, vice president of engagement and impact at Chattanooga Tourism Co., highlighted the city's welcoming atmosphere and the economic impact, noting that annual visitors spend $1.7 billion and support 30,000 jobs in the county.

stories.headline: Space could become next battlefield in conflicts
stories.summary: With Russia's recent satellite hijacking during its Victory Day parade, concerns are rising over the use of satellites in modern warfare. Experts warn that cyberattacks on satellite systems can disrupt communications, affecting land, sea, air, and cyberspace operations. Tom Pace, CEO of NetRise, emphasized the risks to satellite security systems and the importance of protecting supply chains from such threats.

stories.headline: Leaders hope for Russia-Ukraine war end
stories.summary: President Donald Trump announced plans for a face-to-face meeting with Vladimir Putin and Volodymyr Zelenskyy to discuss ending Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The president mentioned arrangements for a trilateral meeting including European leaders, aiming for progress toward ending the conflict. It remains unclear if Putin has fully agreed to these talks, which came shortly after Trump spoke with both leaders.

stories.headline: ‘A result of their labor’
stories.summary: Tyner Middle High Academy opened a new building four years after students initially walked out in protest over poor school conditions. The ribbon-cutting ceremony celebrated the legacy and leadership of the class of 2022 and emphasized teaching students to advocate for themselves and do the right things. The new facility marks the end of a challenging chapter and the start of improved educational infrastructure in Hamilton County.

stories.headline: Texas legislators go back to state, ending walkout
stories.summary: Texas Democrats ended their two-week walkout on Monday, allowing Republican efforts to redraw congressional districts to proceed. The walkout had stalled plans that supported Donald Trump's desire to reshape U.S. House maps. Democrats returned to ensure they do not leave again and to satisfy California's and other states' new congressional boundaries in retaliation for the U.S. commitment to work with allies. The return paves the way for GOP redistricting and after Republicans declared victory in the special session and Democrats rallied, upcoming elections are expected to become highly contested.

stories.headline: Central High unveils its new science wing, first in 100 years
stories.summary: Little Rock School District and city officials showcased the newly added science wing to Central High, the first such addition in almost 100 years. The 67,000-square-foot building includes state-of-the-art science labs and facilities, a 200-seat lecture hall, and a revamped outdoor lunch area. The new wing signaled an important investment in students' futures through a modernized campus. The project was approved by the Little Rock School Board and represents a significant advancement for the school.

stories.headline: Hamas accepts truce proposal as toll climbs
stories.summary: Hamas has accepted a new ceasefire proposal from Arab mediators as the Gaza Strip faces immense devastation with over 62,000 deaths following 22 months of war. The truce offer comes amid ongoing humanitarian catastrophe and starvation risks. U.S. President Donald Trump has cast doubt on some negotiations but indicates willingness to see the return of hostages. Israel plans to reoccupy Gaza City and surrounding areas, warning Hamas and international actors of potential escalation.

stories.headline: City official reports 'bullying' over mural
stories.summary: A Bentonville city council member reports encountering bullying over a mural that has become a center of controversy. Aubrey Patterson, who represents Ward 3, shared that social media backlash and fear have led to targeted attacks on city council members connected to the mural project. Patterson stated that the bullying is personal, involving harm to family members and threats, highlighting community tensions related to the public art.

stories.headline: Putin-Zelenskyy talks in works, Trump says
stories.summary: President Donald Trump has begun arrangements for a face-to-face meeting between Vladimir Putin and Volodymyr Zelenskyy to discuss a pathway to end Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The president announced the progress shortly after speaking with Putin and plans to host Zelenskyy and top European leaders to push for an end to the brutal war. The talks come amid a significant measure of de-escalation on the continent and Trump is pressing Ukraine to make concessions that will only further embolden Putin, though leaders emphasize the importance of fulfilling the campaign promise of ending the war.

stories.headline: Documentarian PBS Rejected
stories.summary: Joel DeMott's documentary 'Seventeen,' which explored the lives of teenagers, was rejected by PBS. DeMott was a public TV series veteran and was 78 years old.

stories.headline: Netflix's Biggest Gamble
stories.summary: Brandon Riegg plans to invest heavily in live shows and sports as the streaming service Netflix shifts strategy to attract viewers amid subscriber challenges.

stories.headline: Pirro Takes On Washington
stories.summary: U.S. Attorney Jeanine Pirro has emerged as a central figure in the president's crime crackdown effort, playing a crucial role in the ongoing investigations.

stories.headline: In Crackdown, D.C.’s Homeless Feel More Pain
stories.summary: New policies in Washington, D.C. aimed at addressing homelessness are causing increased difficulties for homeless individuals. People living near Washington Circle and other parts of the city are experiencing stricter enforcement and reduced tolerance for encampments, leading to heightened pain and challenges among this vulnerable population.

stories.headline: Haitians Fueled Revival in Ohio, But Must Leave
stories.summary: Haitian immigrants in Ohio contributed significantly to the revival of a former prison site, creating jobs and driving the local economy. Many of these workers, however, are facing the prospect of having to leave due to changes in immigration enforcement and visa policies. Community leaders and workers express concern about the potential economic and social impacts.

stories.headline: New Gaza Cease-Fire Plan
stories.summary: Hamas proposed a cease-fire plan that includes releasing Israeli hostages and Palestinian prisoners, aiming to de-escalate ongoing conflict.

stories.headline: Games Show Robots’ Potential, But Your Job Is Safe, for Now
stories.summary: Robotics experts demonstrated robots capable of performing some human jobs in China, including a referee at a soccer match, showcasing advances in robot capabilities. Despite their impressive skills, experts say these robots are unlikely to replace human jobs in the near future, as they are limited in adaptability and other complex functions.

stories.headline: Trump Attacks Voting System
stories.summary: President Trump criticized the current mail-in ballot and voting machines, calling for drastic changes and suggesting the need to eliminate mail-in ballots altogether.

stories.headline: India Braces for 50% Tariffs
stories.summary: India prepares for new U.S. tariffs on American imports that could impact millions of Indian workers and trade between the two nations.

stories.headline: Spain Bolsters Firefighters
stories.summary: In response to a deadly heatwave, Spain has sent around 500 more soldiers as crews from Europe joined to help combat extensive wildfires.

stories.headline: Halting Studies on Disparities
stories.summary: The National Institutes of Health has stopped funding some grant programs that address health disparities and socioeconomic groups in response to controversies surrounding 'woke' science.

stories.headline: Zelensky and Allies Press Trump for Security Guarantees
stories.summary: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, backed by an extraordinary delegation of European leaders, defended his nation's interests at the White House on Monday as President Trump pressed for a quick peace agreement with Russia that would require Ukraine to make significant concessions. European leaders including Keir Starmer, Emmanuel Macron, Friedrich Merz, and Giorgia Meloni warned that if Putin is not stopped in Ukraine, he could take more European territory by force. They called for a security force to protect Ukraine from future Russian aggression as Zelensky urged Trump to support Ukraine despite Mr. Trump’s increasing alignment with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia. The meeting was described as cordial and constructive.

stories.headline: Texas Democrats End Walkout, Clearing Way to Pass New Map
stories.summary: Democrats in the Texas State Legislature ended their nearly two-week walkout which had blocked state redistricting efforts favored by Republicans. Governor Greg Abbott and the state attorney general pursued actions to compel their return, including civil arrest warrants and threats of fines. The walkout was aimed at preventing a vote on a Republican-backed congressional map. Democrats plan to return and continue work on redistricting but now under conditions more favorable to them.

stories.headline: Trump hosts Ukraine’s Zelenskyy
stories.summary: In a significant diplomatic development, former President Donald Trump hosted Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy at the White House on August 18. This meeting marked a notable contrast to their last encounter in February, which had been tense. This time, Zelenskyy wore a black suit and was accompanied by European leaders, using the occasion to thank Trump for his efforts. Both presidents expressed optimism about resolving issues between Russia and Ukraine, highlighting key interactions with French, German, Finnish, and Italian officials during the summit.

stories.headline: Ford Bronco gives superfan an adventure of a lifetime
stories.summary: Tamara Gravelle, a 60-year-old woman from Howell, has turned her passion for Ford Bronco vehicles into a small business and a social club. After acquiring a 2023 Ford Bronco Velocity Blue Wildtrak named "Fiona," she founded the Southern Michigan Ladies Bronco Club, which now has almost 550 members. Gravelle plans to expand and organize off-roading trips to various destinations. Her story highlights her dedication to the vehicle and the community she has built around it.

stories.headline: Michigan apple crop expected to be big haul
stories.summary: Michigan's apple industry is poised for its fourth consecutive year of growth, with an estimated harvest of 30 million bushels slated for 2025. The Michigan Apple Committee reported that this year's crop is valued at approximately 1.26 billion pounds of apples. This estimate reflects an increase from last year's record harvest. The growth is attributed to high-density orchard planting and innovative growing practices, with expectations that larger crops will continue in the future, according to Diane Smith, the executive director of the Michigan Apple Committee.

stories.headline: Optimism after Trump, Zelenskyy meet in DC
stories.summary: The meeting between President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy at the White House on August 18 marked a more positive turn compared to their earlier encounter. Both presidents expressed optimism about ending the war between Russia and Ukraine. The meeting also involved European leaders and focused on security guarantees and moving Trump away from Russian President Vladimir Putin’s conditions for peace. Zelenskyy acknowledged the constructive nature of the discussion and praised strong US support.

stories.headline: Extreme-heat protection rule in limbo
stories.summary: The federal government is considering a rule to protect workers from extreme heat, but its future is uncertain under President Donald Trump's administration. The Trump administration has not acted on the proposed rule, which was developed during the Biden administration, that would mandate protections like water, rest breaks, and other safety protocols at 80 degrees "heat index." Businesses and labor groups are watching closely, with some suspicion the rule may not advance despite its backing from stakeholders.

stories.headline: Law puts Phoenix’s historic districts on edge
stories.summary: New zoning rules from House Bill 2721 in Arizona, allowing owners of single-family lots within one mile of downtown districts to develop multi-family housing options such as duplexes and triplexes, have raised concerns among residents and homeowners associations in Phoenix and Tempe. Many worry that the charm and distinct character of historic neighborhoods may be compromised by increased density and multi-family housing projects. State lawmakers hope the law will boost housing opportunities in the region.

stories.headline: ASU season opener nears
stories.summary: Arizona State's football team is preparing for its season opener with a deeper and more talented roster than recent years. The team returns 16 starters following their recent Big 12 championship win, raising optimism about their performance in the upcoming season.

stories.headline: Phoenix rockers join ’80s tour
stories.summary: Phoenix's psychobilly/punk band Limit Club is taking a break as founder Nick Feratu and bassist Nick Meza tour the country on an '80s nostalgia tour. This move highlights the band's growing popularity and connection to '80s rock culture as they reach new audiences on tour.

stories.headline: Trump pushes meeting between Putin and Zelenskyy
stories.summary: President Donald Trump announced plans for a face-to-face meeting between Vladimir Putin and Volodymyr Zelenskyy to discuss a pathway to ending Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Trump called Putin and began arrangements for the meeting, which aims to end the war and raise the level of direct Russian-Ukrainian negotiations. The announcement came shortly after Trump hosted Zelenskyy and other European leaders to discuss the conflict and ways to promote peace.

stories.headline: 5 charged with drug trafficking
stories.summary: Police arrested five men on Interstate 65 Saturday on drug trafficking charges involving large amounts of THC concentrates and marijuana. The suspects include Prichard residents Jaymond Lamar Gatson, 26, and Russell Seltzer Jr., 23; Mobile residents Jamarion Lavontae King, 22, and Christopher Deshawn Reed, 20; and Gulfport, Mississippi resident Meshak Lazarrick Gay, 29. They were charged with first-degree possession of marijuana and are being held in Morgan County Jail with bail set at $150,000 each.

stories.headline: Decatur man 1 of 2 killed in boat collision
stories.summary: A Decatur man was one of two fishermen killed when their bass boat collided with a commercial barge on the Tennessee River. William Michael Sandlin, 63, was with his lifelong friend Edison Kim Wallace, 66, when the accident occurred near Florence Harbor. Sandlin's body was found drifting about 6 miles from the collision site, and Wallace's body was discovered near the collision around 12:30 a.m. They were fishing on Saturday night when the collision caused them to go overboard.

stories.headline: Ready for senior year
stories.summary: Taylor Maddox, a senior at Athens Renaissance School, decorates her car at Point Mallard Park on Monday, marking a fun tradition for students preparing for their senior year.

stories.headline: City Council hires architect
stories.summary: After years of sitting unused and in disrepair, the proposed renovation of Carrie Matthews Recreation Center is moving forward. The Decatur City Council voted 4-1 to hire NewSouth Architects of Huntsville for $190,900 to provide architectural services involving additional consultant work for design and related repairs. The building, originally constructed in 1969, has had foundation problems causing cracks in the walls. One councilman has pushed to keep it in existence despite threats from other council members to demolish it. The city set aside $1.2 million for the project but estimates could reach $4 million or more.

stories.headline: Dealer to plead guilty in Perry overdose
stories.summary: A drug dealer dubbed the “Ketamine Queen” agreed to plead guilty to several criminal charges related to providing ketamine to actor Matthew Perry, resulting in a fatal overdose in October 2023. Jasveen Sangha, who also sold ketamine to other individuals including fellow actor Cody McLaury, admitted guilt as part of a legal agreement. Authorities state that Sangha was part of a network supplying ketamine, contributing to Perry's deadly overdose and other related incidents.

stories.headline: Extreme heat wave is set to hit Southland
stories.summary: Southern California and the American Southwest are expected to face the most severe heat wave of the season, with temperatures in some areas forecast to approach record highs. The heat wave will last several days and is accompanied by dry conditions that increase wildfire risks, with health warnings advising residents to avoid outdoor exertion and prepare for extreme heat. Authorities urge caution to prevent heat-related illnesses and fires.

stories.headline: Jewish faculty unite in defense of UCLA
stories.summary: Over 360 members of UCLA's Jewish faculty signed a letter condemning what they considered the Trump administration's insufficient and punitive response towards allegations of campus antisemitism. The letter was created to prompt the University of California Board of Regents to include freezing of $584 million in research grant funding as a measure against antisemitism. The group emphasized the importance of strengthening protections beyond existing laws on civil rights and medical facilities.
people: University of California Board of Regents

stories.headline: President attacks mail-in ballots, machines
stories.summary: President Trump stated that he would renew his criticism on mail-in voting after a meeting with Russian leader Vladimir Putin, who reportedly told him that postal voting contributed to his 2020 election loss. The president mentioned plans to take executive actions to prevent mail-ballots from being counted and to ban certain voting machines and barcodes, although some provisions were blocked by courts. His statements emphasize distrust of the election system under the current administration.

stories.headline: California cap-and-trade at crossroads; billions at stake
stories.summary: California's cap-and-trade program, which aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, faces challenges as lawmakers, industry groups, and environmental advocates debate its future beyond the 2030 expiration date. Governor Gavin Newsom supports extending the program to 2045, but there's disagreement on its authorization and structure. The program covers significant emissions but needs to evolve to meet updated climate targets with discussions focused on allowances, credits, and auction revenues.

stories.headline: TRUMP WANTS PUTIN, ZELENSKY TO MEET
stories.summary: President Trump proposed a meeting between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to seek peace after years of conflict. Trump suggested accompanying the talks with the U.S. and emphasized a desire to resolve the war. The Kremlin's response remains unclear, and the president's call for negotiations has drawn mixed reactions, as Ukrainian and European leaders remain cautious about Russia's intentions.
